The plant's leaves are capable of photosynthesis even in low-light conditions, thanks to their specialized chloroplast structures. Its flowers, which bloom only once every 50 years, emit a faint, sweet fragrance that attracts specific pollinators. Due to its unique adaptations and limited habitat, Symphyandra pangaea is considered a living relic of ancient botanical evolution.
